Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.

Name: Mrs. Selden C. Chamberlin
Address: Kelston, Sask.
Birthplace: Cumberland, Ontario near Ottawa

1. Introductory Questions
   What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? March 1913
   Where did you set up housekeeping? On a farm
   Where had you been living before that? Cumberland, Ontario
   For how many people did you prepare meals? Two
   How far was it to your nearest store? 25 miles
   How often could a visit be made to the store? Usually once a week
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
   Flour, sugar, salt, soap, rice, beans, dried fruit etc.

2. Flour and Other Grain Products
   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Herbert's
   Around 1919 we bought grain and got flour around 1/2 sacks at a time
   In what quantities did you buy it? 1/2 sacks
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 3.00 cents
   How much did you use graham flour? 2 sacks
   Whole wheat flour? Herbert's
   Was flour milled locally? Yes
   How far away? 25 miles
   What year? 1918
   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? about 60 cents
   What other grain products did you use? Bran & Rye flour
   Cornmeal? Yes
   Whole wheat? No
   Farine? Yes
   Other? Rolled Wheat
   Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Cracked wheat from Herbert Mill
   How did you grind it?
1912. Chamberlin, Mrs. Selden C., Kelstern.

1. INTERESTING QUESTIONS

That year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? March 1913

Where did you set up housekeeping? On a farm

There had you been living before that? In Saskatchewan, Ontario

For how many people did you prepare your food? 2

How far was it to your nearest store? 25 miles

How often did you visit by bus to the store? Once a week

What groceries did you usually buy in those early years?

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

Have brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Parco

In what quantities did you buy 1912? 100 lbs. at a time

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 95 cents

How much did you use prairie flour? 48 lbs.

Whole wheat flour? Huber's

Was flour called locally? Yes

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 60 cents

Did other grain products did you use? Corn meal

Oats? Rolled

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes

How did you grind it? With a hand mill
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 1.00 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $2.50.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Golden Syrup.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 2 lb.

At what price? $1.00.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Kept at home.

Butter? Always kept. Eggs? Kept. Cheese?

What was the price of butter? As low as 10¢ or eggs? 10¢ each.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.

Did you make butter? Yes.

What kind of cheese? Cottage.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Canned pork.

Fresh beef, sometimes from local.

How did you get fresh meat? Butchering our own.

How often did you get fresh meat? Monthly.

How did you preserve meat? Brine.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes.

If so what year was it organized? 1910.

Did you use game? Occasionally. What kinds? Quail.

For how long? 1910-1915.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Canned salmon always had some on hand.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Canned.

Kinds? Canned salmon, herring.
In what quantity did you buy? (in ounces) ... 10.0.0.0.0.

What was the price? (for a ten pound sack of rice) ... $2.46.

At what price? ... $2.00.

Did you make any purchases? ... Yes.

What kind of cheese? ... That kind of cheese.

Did you make any purchases? ... Yes.

What was your meat supply in the early part of the year? ... Fresh meat.

How did you get fresh meat? ... By killing animals.

How often did you get fresh meat? ... Weekly.

Did you preserve meat? ... Yes.

Was there a "meat ring" in your neighborhood? ... No.

If so, what year was it organized? ... 1918.

Did you take games? ... Yes.

For how long? ... That part did that play in the family diet? ... Samuel Salmon

Was the dish fresh, cured, or canned? ... Canned.

Kind of food purchased from whom? ... Samuel Salmon

Carmel Salmon, A. W. Murray
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? At what price? 

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Price?

What other beverages were used?

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?

Could you get potatoes at the store?

If not, where from?

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of: 1913-14

Potatoes Cabbage Carrots Onions

Turnips Beets

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans?

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)?

What weight? How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)?

What was the price of prunes?

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? No

peas corn beans Saskatoon berries

other foods

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1913

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1920

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1919

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Canning

To what extent? About 200 qts. fruit, 150 vegetables

Did you make your own vinegar? Home made Better

But like the taste of store Vinegar Better
6. How much did you buy? (bushel or crown) $3.00

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) ... Well ...

How far was this water from your home? ... 100 feet ...

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ... Pail ...

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We still use the water from the well 29 ft. well dug in 1909, one of the best in the district and many of the neighbours hauled from here. We have had a cistern since 1918.
There did not get water for drinking until 1913 (in 1912, there was none).

How far was this water from your house? 1/4 mile.

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank) Pail.

We first started homesteading in 1909, but the well was dug in 1909 by the neighbors. We have had a well since then.

From Roe. We have had a well since then.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Bought with my own when I had the fat.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes, wood ashes?

What kind of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Royal Bath Soap.

Sunlight.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Coal.

Where did you get your fuel? Morse.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Still use a coal stove and furnace only we haul it from Kelstern started about 1922-4½ miles from here.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates)

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove made? Little Gem from Eaton's.

That year was it purchased? Eaton's Price? $3.50.

What type of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade)

Aluminum.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

Earthenware.

When did you first see enamel ware? We had what we called agate ware before I came here.

Aluminum?

I had aluminum frying pan, coffee pot, tea pot, double boilers & kettle given as a wedding present in 1918. Wear ever.
11. S/N#3 Did you buy lumber easy or make your own? If you did your own, did you use your own saw? How much did you pay per board foot?

12. Fuel. Did you use a coal stove and furnace? Only we have it from Kittery Point House about 19 x 4 1/2 miles from here.

13. For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the summer? Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates.)

What year was it purchased? What year was it purchased? (Give dates.)

For preparing food? (Give dates.) When did you first cook stove? (Give dates.)

Then did you first use electric? (Give dates.)

How were the first used without any called? (Give dates.)

Had aluminum cooking utensils & kettle pot? (Give dates.)

Given as a wedding present? (Give dates.)

19/13. Wear ever...
16. Wrapping and containers

mention any changes which you recall in the wrapping and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

we used to get biscuits in tiny wooden boxes now are cardboard.

tea in lead plugs.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer, about 1920.

Evelyn Chamberlin 6 yrs Anna Chamberlin 4 yrs.
Russell Chamberlin 1 yr.

July Breakfast: Toast Egg Jam Coffee & Milk
Dinner: Cured Pork Egg Potato Fresh Beans
Milk Pudding Tea & Meat
Supper: Cured Pork Egg Potato Fresh Vegetables
Canned Fruit Tea & Milk

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

about 1919 after we built our house.

Mrs. & Mrs. Hobbs Edith 19 Harvey 15-
Orville 13 Winnie 12 Edna 7.

Menu: Turkey & Cranberries Jellies
Potato & Turnips Pickles
Plum Pudding & Sauce

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Never.

The diet sometimes was monotonous in the thirties but we never were near starvation.
17. Give a typical dinner (or breakfast, dinner) supper for the family. You can serve it in the living room or dining room. If you have a large family, you may want to move the table to another room.

18. That year did you have your first Christmas dinner in eastern Kentucky?

19. How do you feel about our house? We moved into our new home in 1949 after we bought our house.

20. What was the most memorable event in the thirties? We never went near starvation.
In early days we bought in large quantities from Saloon men travelling around (tea & coffee in tins) anywhere (peaches, pears etc.) were cheaper than here. But a lot cheaper than here. In 1918 we could a range house well food storage build a road out of storage room. So we lived in a 12 x 16 shack so that we could go to Beef River.
21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home preserved foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

22. Please add any other comments or experiences of buying groceries.

In early days we bought our large quantities of tea and coffee in tins travelling from 10 to 25 cents each. These articles were dry packed. I know they were Borson's brand. I know their price. I remember the prices. In 1918 we could get a range house well paid $3000. We paid rent in a 12 x 16 shack so that we lived in a room with a window.
